awd_titl_txt: Designing and Evaluating a CS + Law Introduction to Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The significance and importance of this project lies in developing a novel and attractive form of a college-level introductory Computer Science course. The course will integrate the traditional topics of a programming-based introductory Computer Science course with a consideration of the law and public policy issues surrounding online privacy and security. For example, a topic like 2-dimensional arrays will be illustrated by building a map of murders in a city like Chicago instead of the board of some computer game; and will be accompanied by discussion of the pros and cons of  a Police Department's use of such maps for predictive policing together with the legal issues predictive policing raises.
 
The specific education research goals of the project are testing three claims. First, whether new introductory curricula, with content drawn from a field (law) whose students are roughly 50 percent female, can attract more women to major in Computer Science at a public university. Second, whether the same practices aimed at increasing the participation of women in computing might also increase the participation of other underrepresented student groups. Third, whether an introductory Computer Science course grounded in a subject of wide interest to much of the general public (law, and especially online privacy and security law) will succeed in drawing more non-CS majors into taking additional Computer Science courses.

por.por_cntn:
We created a version of a first college course in computer science ("CS 1") that has a strong law and public policy theme and have offered it at University of Illinois Chicago (UIC) several times. It has recently been given its own course number. In Computer Science, the course is one of several choices for the first introductory course for computer science majors and minors. 

In the course, students learn to create and use programs in the Python programming language to analyze and illustrate various issues arising from law and public policy, with a particular focus on security and privacy. They learn a little bit about "how to think like a lawyer," and a lot about "how to think like a computer scientist."

We have measured how successful the course has been and published our results in the computer science education literature. We have also made the entirety of the course materials freely available for instructors at any other institution to use. 

Several key goals of this course were:

  • To give students the background to appreciate and work on the myriad issues at intersection of computer science and public policy. 
  • To give students some introductory training in data science, in addition to computer science.
  • To simultaneously provide a full education in CS 1. To meet this goal, it was important that this course do as good a job of educating students in computer science as a standard first course in computer science
  • To draw more women into the study of computer science. Women are severely underrepresented in computer science, whereas women make up about half of US law students. 

What is meant by "law and public policy theme" is that almost all the examples presented in the class, and almost all the homework assignments, are into legal and public policy topics. For example, students begin the course by learning how to implement some historical cryptosystems in Python, while simultaneously learning about the current state of US law on when the government can force somebody to decrypt their files. Later, students learn both about how to write a web crawler, and what web crawling activities my raise legal issues under the US Computer Fraud and Abuse Act and perform basic data analytics on the Supreme Court Justices' voting records from the past 75 years. Students also learn some basic network analysis and learn about its use in predictive policing and surveillance generally.

What is meant by "first college course in computer science" is that the course includes all the learning outcomes found in a typical CS 1 course for computer science minors and majors at any US college or university. Some of the key learning outcomes in all such courses include:

  • The big ideas of computer science, often summarized as computational thinking
  • How to design, write, and debug medium-small computer programs in some programming language. For our course, we used Python, which is the most used programming language for CS 1 courses around the country today.
  • Some of the underlying knowledge about topics such as where data is stored in a computer's memory for a particular programming language construct that differentiate expert computer programmers from novices.

We measured student outcomes and knowledge in this course and in a standard CS 1 course being offered at UIC during at the same time during several different semesters. We found that students were roughly equally successful in obtaining the key computer science learning outcomes across the two classes. This was a good outcome, because instructors have to spend some time in this course covering both an overview of some legal topics, and of some data science topics, neither of which is taught in the standard course. 

Because of disruptions to course scheduling caused by the pandemic, this course was not taught during the 2020-2021 school year, but it will be offered in Spring 2022 semester, and regularly going forward. During the funded period of the grant, this law themed CS 1 course attracted many interested students, but did not attract significantly more women than the standard course.
